posts.name: Steve Martin
posts.cooked:
Deployed code for the first time on Standard AM chassis, Tough Mini Gear box, and 2 CIM motors. The drive motors are fighting each other. We have double checked electrical connections and attempted running a single motor with the same results. Deployed code is command based- using driving code from WPIâ€™s example found on their Github. Any pointers?

main/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/hatchbottraditional

posts.cooked:
coach7318:

We have double checked electrical connections and attempted running a single motor with the same results.

Mind clarifying real quick? Are you saying the two motors on 1 side are fighting each other?

Little confused when you say when you run a single motor you get the same result.

Since you are running CIM motors, my suggestion is to quickly reverse the polarity of the CIM that is running the opposite direction. Youâ€™re already setting one side to inverted in your code, which is correct, so that should resolve the issue for you quickly.

A quick way to check motors fighting each other is by doing breaker pulls. You can put in one breaker at a time and run your drivetrain to see if its moving in your desired direction.

posts.name: Steve Martin
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

check motors fighting each other is

Not necessarily fighting each other. Awful crunchy sound in 3/4 CIM motors. I ended up running each separately by isolating in the code and only one motor sounds okay and doesnâ€™t chitter.

All of them sound fine when run using a drill to supply electricity to individual motors.

posts.name: Sunny, Leveson
posts.cooked: Are they following? We had a similar issue with falcons and it came down to the follow command not working well lately

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
coach7318:

All of them sound fine when run using a drill to supply electricity to individual motors.

This tends to point away from a mechanical issue (e.g. reversed gear or binding). Check that you arenâ€™t setting the voltage twice (to different values) in each loop - this can sometimes cause a similar effect.  Also check for loose wiring, both the power and control side.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
What motor controllers are you using? What are there LEDs doing?

How did you isolate the motor controllers in your code?
